content: The mind-body problem originated from the scientific revolution's reinterpretation of qualitative and purposive features of the world as mental appearances, following its description of the physical world in quantitative, spatio-temporal terms.
The primary challenge in reducing the mental to the physical is the irreducible subjectivity of consciousness, which cannot be adequately described by objective physical accounts.
The irreducible subjectivity of consciousness implies that reality encompasses more than what can be described by the physical sciences, necessitating an expanded understanding of the natural order.
